instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3115A: What is 820-3115A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.U5701: What is U5701? this is the keyboard controller chip that takes the keyboard and trackpad input and turns it into a USB device signal for the machine to process. If replacing a keyboard doesn’t fix an issue with keys not typing, check all traces between keyboard connector and this IC. This chip has programming so it must be replaced from a similar, ideally identical board. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
Newbie, my first post, please cut me some slack, do not have all the lingo down yet:
This machine has green light on mag and will boot with chime as soon as I plug in mag charger. The screen stays black, but when I put in external monitor it will show logo and load about 1/3 and hang. So far I disconnected  the internal HDD and tried to boot of external HDD, same result, boot and hang. I disconnected keyboard and booted with external keyboard, same. Did the SMC reset with no response, PRAM reset same, no change. Battery I disconnected and reconnected, still same.Disconnected machine's display, to eliminate possible short in there. Now I suppose I must go in, my hunch is SMC. Any more things to try before I take out the board, and if not, where do I look first, once the board is out, please? I felt heat over the GPU just using my finger. Could it be a similar cap issue supplying the GPU as in the 2010 15" machines?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
Try new BIOS, with clean ME.
Run EFI ASD, maybe reports some error.

BTW, does it run Linux Live, or Windows Live?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message: Did you try another SATA Cable? Bad cable can cause hang on boot. Also could be the PCH getting hot which would be bad

threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 42472"]Try new BIOS, with clean ME.
Run EFI ASD, maybe reports some error.

BTW, does it run Linux Live, or Windows Live?[/QUOTE]

OK 2informaticos, thank you for the pointers again: I have been trying to inform myself on these processes you suggested, but I am running into walls.
As for the clean ME , I looked, amongst others, at this link: [URL="https://www.laboneinside.com/how-to-fix-bios-me-region-problem/"]https://www.laboneinside.com/how-to-...egion-problem/[/URL]
At the end of the article it says: "That’s it, your problem has been resolved. [B]Now, just reprogram your clean ME Bios Bin[/B]." Sounds scary, since I do not know how to reprogram my clean ME Bios ...yet. So I cannot pursue this...unless I have more info.
Regarding the EFI ASD, I found out that I need ASD3S150, but so far cannot find a reliable link, nor any link really, for this utility,
Could you please clue me know how to get into this aspect of fixing the board?
Finally, Regarding Linux Live versus Windows Live, I assume that it is Linux, and not Windows. It is a friends machine, who is allowing me to try and fix it, to learn about board repair, and it had MAC OSX running on it, which is more like Linux, right?
I am a junior member, heavy on the junior part, I suppose..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
Machine should run Linux Live.
You can also install Windows on it.
Disconnect internal disk when do such test...

If you don't have Medusa 2, then need to pull out SPI chip and reprogram it with external programmer; like CH341, TL866, nano BIOS programmer, many out there.
Remember to save the backup!!!

First of all, run ASD.
If your machine is Early-2011, needs 3S144.
For Late-2012, needs 3S150.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
I managed to get the ASD3S150 installed on USB,and am currently running the EFI test. Took a bit of doing, such as SMC reset,as well as 1)disconnect existing on-board screen, 2) HDD and 3) battery, to convince the machine to display on an external monitor. So I selected "All Tests" and to "Continue on Error".
While it works I am puzzled over the other three .dmg images I received from my ASD3S150 download, I followed the instruction regarding the first one, namely partition for EFI and OS, and copy on those two onto my appropriate USB partition . I am confused what to do with the other three .dmgs....I am missing something here..
OK, machine passed the EFI test, all 46 tests are green. Where to go from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message: Ok, I downloaded the firmware and the Intel easy Clean ME, but forgive my current lack of knowledge: How to deploy these windows programs on a Mac computer which does not boot is an enigma to me? I have been searching here and googled there, but any clues and /or discussion assume that the reader is already in the know. I am at the beginning here. OK, I finally found some info on Medusa 2. Looks very easy and useful...expensive though. Or should I just replace the chip, if this is the likely culprit?[url]www.ebay.com/itm/PROGRAMMED-EFI-CHIP-2012-APPLE-MACBOOK-PRO-13-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B-EMC-2554-BIOS-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>/301463507370?_trkparms=aid%3D555018%26algo%3DPL.SIM%26ao%3D1%26asc%3D52885%26meid%3D0b1910aa52764ca1a8a0de528f83f374%26pid%3D100005%26rk%3D1%26rkt%3D1%26sd%3D112692838938%26itm%3D301463507370&_trksid=p2047675.c100005.m1851[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
You MUST remove SPI chip <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and reprogram it with external programmer; connected to another (Windows) computer, through USB.
CH341 programmer is about 5 bucks and is good enough...
When you get the programmer, let us know if need the BIOS dump with clean ME.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
So I now have my EEPROM BIOS USB Programmer CH341A + SOIC8 Clip + 1.8V Adapter + SOIC8 Adapter at hand.
I also have my bios update folder with ImUpdate, SFlash16, and 128MBDOS IMG File. I am trying to the best of my current still very limited understanding to figure out the next step without doing damage. 
Could I please have a pointer on how to proceed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
You don't need 1.8V adapter in this case.
Upload somewhere your BIOS backup.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message: Still keep googling for a good video in English to do these jobs on a MBP: Make a bios backup, and how to properly use the the re-programming tools I now have. There is not much out there...at least in language I can understand.Also wonder if I still need to unsolder the chip, given that I have my handy connector wires which can clamp on the chip and tie to the USB. I 'll keep looking....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
Don't waste time with the clamp.
Remove the chip and place it in SOP8-DIP8 adapter.
Then read and save the content (backup).
Verify two times if chip content and saved backup are identical.
Do NOT erase the chip before verify is done.
Upload somwhere the backup and wait to get back the correct file.
Erase chip and write new BIOS dump.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message: Thank you for giving me something intelligible to proceed with, 2informaticos.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
Before I venture into the BIOS reprogramming, which is still quite scary/vague for me at this point, I decided to have a look under the logic board to see what I might find, and to check the power rails: So far I found amongst the regular chips:
1 Potato chips in a bed of dust, 
​​​​​​<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.59V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.493V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>:  2.22 V on various test points, 
Then I nearly burned my finger on  L5801 which is on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_P18V5S5</SIGNAL> ( Booster for sensors) , which showed OL across the coil and short to ground on both sides.
Could this be the culprit, since the Apple logo is showing up and the bar is getting to the 1/3 point points to passing the first part of POST just not able to get to the second phase when the dedicated GPU and its drivers are loaded (NVIDIA GeForce 320M)  That last sentence did not come from me, but does make vaguely sense to me....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
Remove <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR> and test again <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>.
If you get correct value, then see if you get into OSX.
If yes, resolder <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR> and dig in <CHIP>U5805</CHIP> area.
If L5801 still hot after disconnect trackpad cable, <CHIP>U5805</CHIP> need to be replaced; or trackpad will not move the cursor.
Also check <DIODE>D5802</DIODE>.

So, don't touch BIOS untill solve this problem...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message: I removed <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR>, which resulted in fluctuating voltage measured at P2 of the removed <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR>, as well as on P1 of <CAPACITOR>C5800</CAPACITOR> /L5800 respectively. At first reading it was 2.7V, a minute later it had gone up to 3.8V only to go down again a minute later to 2V and ending up at 0V. <DIODE>D5802</DIODE> is now also at 0V. Things were heating up at first measuring, noticeable at <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>  and at <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>  but that has now stopped...Can you make any sense of this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message: Shall I put <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR> back in to see if it I at least get some voltage back these <CAPACITOR>C5800</CAPACITOR> and L5800?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
What is the voltage for pin17/<CHIP>U7200</CHIP>?
And resistance to ground too.

C/L5800 are both connected before <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR>.
You can remove L5800 to see if that helps.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
I measured P17 on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> , it shows 0V. There also is no short to ground , it shows OL in Diode Mode.
The next task you gave me I  is very confusing to my noob brain: Neither L5800 nor <CAPACITOR>C5800</CAPACITOR> are present on my board!!! There are the pads where they belong, according to my boardview, but they look like they never had seen any solder. (This is now the second time where I run into this in my learning about board repair, ie: where boardview and schematics clearly state that that there should be a component, but nothing is there) Obviously here is something I am not getting (yet) , besides L5800 and <CAPACITOR>C5800</CAPACITOR>.  They must exist as they are in line to <SIGNAL>PP5V_5_CUMULUS</SIGNAL>, going to the IPD Connector J5800.  ????

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
Some components are oprional, don't worry about them...

Pin 17/<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is the <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> output; you MUST have voltage there.
I the same rail which goes to <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR>.

Post some voltages for <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, 16, 3, 8, 13, 6, 17 (again).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
As I mentioned in post 29: After I had removed <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR>, it resulted in voltage first increasing and then decreasing over a minute or so to 0V. (measured at P2 of the removed <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR>, as well as on P1 of <CAPACITOR>C5800</CAPACITOR> /L5800 respectively). At first reading it was 2.7V, a minute later it had gone up to 3.8V only to go down again a minute later to 2V and ending up at 0V. 

Regarding  <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> today:
P17:   0V
P16:  12.72V
P13:  3.06
P3, 6, 8, and all other pins = 0V

Something packed it in evidently, after I had removed <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR>.

Optional components....OK, one day I will understand...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
First check resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> line.
Be sure didn't make short in some point to ground, when removed <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR>.

Now seems to miss <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>; confirm that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
I checked resistance to ground for the 5V-S5
at the former <RESISTOR>R5805</RESISTOR> contact points P2= 0.4 ohm, at P1= 5.3ohm
It looks clean where I removed the resistor I see no damage which might cause a short. I can send a picture of area if that helps.
I measured <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>  at <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>, and there it voltage is present at  P2= 3.51V.
While there, I measured the other contacts on <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> as well, they are all 0V except for P1=3.51V and P3= 3.35V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
"P2= 0.4 ohm"
Check why...
You still have short on <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>, even lower like before.
Should be easiest to find it now, injecting voltage.
Maybe <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> got bad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
Thank you 2informaticos.
This will be the first time I fire up my new DC power supply, and I am a bit nervous since there is so much I do not know yet.
If I am going to inject 5V on <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> would you tell me where would be a safe point to to so? I just want to make sure I do not make it worst...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B boots about 1/3 into progress bar then hangs
threads.message:
You cannot inject 5V into 0.4 ohm; that means more than 10A...
Start with 1V and go up, maintaing ampers bellow current limit; 5A for usual bench power supply.
